The following is the mathlib proof of the Wedderburn-Artin theorem in mathlib:

/-- The **Wedderburn–Artin Theorem**: an Artinian simple ring is isomorphic to a matrix
ring over the opposite of the endomorphism ring of its simple module. -/
theorem exists_ringEquiv_matrix_end_mulOpposite :
    ∃ (n : ℕ) (_ : NeZero n) (I : Ideal R) (_ : IsSimpleModule R I),
      Nonempty (R ≃+* Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) (Module.End R I)ᵐᵒᵖ) := by
  have ⟨n, hn, S, hS, ⟨e⟩⟩ := (isIsotypic R R).linearEquiv_fun
  refine ⟨n, hn, S, hS, ⟨.trans (.opOp R) <| .trans (.op ?_) (.symm .mopMatrix)⟩⟩
  exact .trans (.moduleEndSelf R) <| .trans e.conjRingEquiv (endVecRingEquivMatrixEnd ..)

Is there a way to extract the fact that specifically the map R→Mn(EndR(I))R \to M_n(\mathrm{End}_R(I))R→Mn​(EndR​(I)), which sends rrr to m↦rmm \mapsto rmm↦rm, is an isomorphism? The reason I need this is to prove that a group representation is absolutely irreducible iff its base change to the algebraic closure is absolutely irreducible. The informal proof runs as follows: if VVV is an irreducible representation of GGG over kkk, then by Schur's lemma we have Endk‾[G](V)=k‾\mathrm{End}_{\overline{k}[G]}(V) = \overline{k}Endk[G]​(V)=k. Then the natural map k‾[G]→Mn(k‾)\overline{k}[G] \to M_n(\overline{k})k[G]→Mn​(k) is surjective by the claim above. Hence for any field extension FFF of k‾\overline{k}k, the map F[G]→Mn(F)F[G] \to M_n(F)F[G]→Mn​(F) is surjective, hence VFV_FVF​ is irreducible.

Your outline seems to be missing the MulOpposite.
I think absolute irreducibility is equivalent to k→EndR(I)k\to\mathrm{End}_R(I)k→EndR​(I) being bijective?

noncomputable def AW_n : ℕ := (isIsotypic R R).linearEquiv_fun.choose

instance AW_n_neZero : NeZero (AW_n R) := (isIsotypic R R).linearEquiv_fun.choose_spec.1

etc etc; you'll finish with

def AW_map : R ≃+* Matrix (Fin (AW_n R)) (Fin (AW_n R) (Module.End R (AW_I R)ᵐᵒᵖ := <what it says in the proof>

The proof of Wedderburn Artin goes like: RRR is isomorphic to InI^nIn as RRR-modules, so Rop≅EndR(R)≅EndR(In)≅Mn(EndR(I))R^\mathrm{op}\cong \mathrm{End}_R(R)\cong \mathrm{End}_R(I^n)\cong M_n(\mathrm{End}_R(I))Rop≅EndR​(R)≅EndR​(In)≅Mn​(EndR​(I)) as rings.

Are you saying that in the mathlib proof of Artin-Wedderburn, the isomorphism constructed is not rrr to m↦rmm \mapsto rmm↦rm?
For sure it's .trans (.opOp R) <| .trans (.op (.trans (.moduleEndSelf R) <| .trans e.conjRingEquiv (endVecRingEquivMatrixEnd ..))) (.symm .mopMatrix)
and that seems to be what Junyan wrote. Note that the isomorphism R≅InR\cong I^nR≅In is unspecified; it's coming from (isIsotypic R R).linearEquiv_fun which again is just an existence statement.

Stepan Nesterov said:

Are you saying that in the mathlib proof of Artin-Wedderburn, the isomorphism constructed is not rrr to m↦rmm \mapsto rmm↦rm?

RRR acts on RRR by right multiplication (the first ring isomorphism), and this action doesn't fix the copies of III s.
There is no map R→EndR(I)R\to\mathrm{End}_R(I)R→EndR​(I) in general if RRR is noncommutative, since m↦rmm\mapsto rmm↦rm wouldn't be RRR-linear.

Sorry I'm saying nonsense
I think I mean R→EndEndR(I)(I)R \to \mathrm{End}_{\mathrm{End}_R(I)}(I)R→EndEndR​(I)​(I)
Where III is a right EndR(I)\mathrm{End}_R(I)EndR​(I)-module
So this is the setting of Jacobson density instead; the proof of Wedderburn Artin doesn't involve such nested End.
And is Jacobson density not in mathlib?

    ∃ a : A, ∀ m ∈ s, f m = a • m := by

    Function.Surjective (Module.toModuleEnd A (S := End A M) M) := by
